text:
‘Well, what do you want? Who are you?’ the workman shouted. 

Raskolnikov stepped back inside. 

‘I want to take a flat. I am looking round.’

‘It’s not the time to look at rooms at night!’ the workman replied. 

‘The floors have been washed. Will they be painted? Is there no blood?’

‘What blood?’ 

‘The old woman and her sister were murdered here. There was a perfect pool.’

‘But who are you?’ the workman asked, uneasy. 

‘Who am I? Come to the police station, I’ll tell you.’

The workmen stared at him, amazed. 

‘It’s time for us to go,’ the elder workman said. 

‘Very well, come along,’ Raskolnikov said, indifferent. 

He went downstairs slowly. 

‘Hey, porter!’ he called in the gateway.

Several people stood by, staring. 

‘What do you want?’ a porter asked.

‘Have you been to the police office?’

‘I’ve just been there. What do you want?’

‘Is it open?’

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov, seeking a flat, engages in a tense conversation about a recent murder at the location.
